reviewText:
Early Access Review

Door kickers is great. Its easy to understand but hard to master and the single screen levels are great for killing five mins here and there.

The game is about guiding a Armed team of presumably cops through a level capping bad guys, saving hostages and defusing bombs. It’s like a top down version of rainbow six. The levels are varied as are the unit types and the game play is fast yet addictive. You’ll want to get you times as fast as possible while incurring no team deaths again very similar to rainbow six.

I also respect the developers of this indie title, they’ve been working hard to continually update the game and the updates are always big deals that add a lot of new content or features. They are also very good at interacting with their consumers and those that bought the game early. It’s jus t anice touch of class that is sometimes lacking. The integration of Steam Workshop is also awesome.

In all Doorkickers is awesome and I’ve spent a lot of time with it. I genuinely look forward to the next update as they always do something pretty cool.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kicking down doors has never been so much fun. In fact, I don't remember the last time I had this much fun kicking down a door with my mighty boot of door bashiness.

I have been longing to play a tactical game of this sort. I was dissapointed by the previous Jagged Alliance (the kickstarter one looks nice, but time will tell), slightly bored like Frozen Synapse (which I might add, is a pretty damn good game, but the presentation didn't work out for me).  Door Kickers made the cut for me. Of course, we had the amazing X-Com. But there's something about Door Kickers. Is it the speed at which your plan is executed? The thrill of raiding a villa full of bad guys and unlucky hostages and making it out without a single casualty on the good guy side? Door Kicker is simply amazing.

Great presentation, sound and above all, gameplay. Amazing detailed top down views from your average training killhouse to villas and apartments. Great system for planning out your moves, and your swat guy armaments and tool are great, from trusty crowbar to m4s and boots of door bashing+1. Be it in real time or pausy-planning-unpausy-time, the gameplay feels rewarding. And it's always a pleasure taking down those horde of baddies :)

Door Kicker win the cake for me, as a rewarding, well thought out, tactical game.

reviewText:
If you like tactical games, or even have a passing interested in strategy games, I highly recommend picking this one up. If you are like me and played and loved old school SWAT/Rainbow Six games, then you owe it to yourself to buy this right now.

Cons:

- A bit pricey compared to other indie games of similar (high) quality
- Some difficulty spikes: the progression of difficulty in both campaigns and separate maps could be smoother, though it never feels impossible

Pros:

- Great music
- Amazingly simple yet effective controls
- Overall wonderful atmosphere for such simple graphics
- Nice sense of progression (even with failed missions) with both individual team member and squad leveling without it entirely revolving around power gained from leveling up
- Lots of content, with multiple campaigns, individual maps with rankings, a random mission generator, a mission builder, and plenty more to download on steam workshop

Meh:

- Sound effects are merely ok
- Some odd bugs here and there that take you out of the experience, but aren't game-breaking
- Destructible environments would've been nice

TLDR: Well worth your time and effort as a strategy gamer.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very solid game. Feel quite believable, everything is implemented with tradeoffs, all situation dependent so every mission really feels different.

In terms of difficulty, they really manage to walk the thin line between easy but boring and hard but rewarding. I wouldn't quite call it unforgiving, I mean you don't ALWAYS pay for mistakes, but things can often go bad very easily if you don't pay attention.

More importantly, I almost never felt like I should have been allowed to be able to do something but wasn't, never felt like it was unfair in any way nor does it feel like you're controlling idiots. Just to illustrate the point, there was no end to my frustration in Rainbow Six when I couldn't get my team to even throw a flashbang around corner, not comparing games themselves, just the feeling.

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best tactical games I've ever played.

Every mission requires precise planning, a good loadout for the situation, and teamwork. You can't just run in and shoot up the place and win. You must use your squad to execute precise maneuvers in order to complete the objective with minimal SWAT casualties. For example, using a spy camera will give you the upper hand when breaching a door, so you know the enemy positions before entering the room, and your squad will know where to aim beforehand. In other situations, using the spy camera is not the best option, because there might only be a small hallway on the other side of the door, and checking first might slow you down, as you are racing the clock. Most missions will have an objective time goal, which you must beat to get the maximum amount of points, so completing the mission in a quick, clean manner is the optimal goal.

Now, twenty dollars might seem like a hefty price for a game like this, but there are three main campaigns, each with at least an hour or more in them, and a ton of single missions, mostly involving just clearing a compound of bad guys. The Steam Workshop offers many player-made campaigns, many of which are very well-made and add many hours of playtime to this game. In my opinion, $20 is a worthy price for this game, but if this isn't at the top of your wishlist, I would reccomend buying it when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
A fantastic squad-based shooter. I played both this and Breach and Clear in close proximity to one another and love the flexibility Door Kickers in how you play it - you can play it as nearly a RTS and give commands on the fly (though you can't give commands to bulk groups of folks) or you can draft a single plan for the entire mission for all of your troopers - complete with commands to synchronize actions - or anywhere in between (I tend to plot out the first room or two and then react dynamically to whatever is happening by pausing and drawing up new plans for the next few seconds).

Cons - you do tend to see the same layouts over and over again - even with random missions, troopers aren't radically different from one another in their personalities.

I also wish that there was some form of negotiation option to try to talk to folks while also inserting your SWAT team and performing recon or stealth takedowns - something approaching aspects of SWAT 2 with occasional non-violent resolutions. I do wish that more missions featured 4 man teams.

Great tactical game and an absolute blast. Very much recommend this title.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Really nice squad level pause-enabled RTS with a SWAT theme. I've played both this and Breach and Clear and like both but Door Kickers gives you a little more control over precision operations. Think of a top-down Rainbow Six, with role-playing game elements too. Very addicting for those interested in this type of game, and with lots to do: plenty of single missions with achievements, several campaigns, a random scenario generator, and a map maker. There are already many user-made contributions to the community. The developer really seems to enjoy working on this game and there is what seems to be pretty good involvement on their site's bulletin board. This game is a steal on sale and bargain even at regular price.

reviewText:
Impressevly good tactical strategy. Last time I was so exited by tactial game in 2005, it was SWAT4. Door Kickers is something middle of SWAT4 and Frozen Synapse. Before the mission you picking troopers and gear like it was in SWAT4, and mission gameplay is very similar to Frozen Synapse, but here you can set pause whenever you want.

The game has a lot of content: 5 classes of troopers, lots of unlockable guns, 3 branches in perks tree, 5 campains, more then 80 single missions, level editor and level generator(!). If it's not enough for you, visit Steam Workshop, there are a lot of extra content created by community. As I can see the game is fully moddable - guns mods, realism mods and visual mods are available.

Game control is very tabletishh, but as i can see there is no tablet version of this game. Another bad thing is that Door Kickers is single player game only, but as written in description of the game - (but MP might come later)".

4/5"
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Door Kickers. Tactical, top down simulation game in which you are in full control of a highly trained SWAT team. Oh yeah, it's brilliant.
The objectives are usually very straight-forward: eliminate all hostiles (or tangos, as they call them), save the captives and/or apprehend the suspects(s). However, every level offers a new location, with unpredictable enemy spawns and new tactics to be developed. Over time and the completion of missions four new classes will be unlocked: Pointman (the starter  class), Assualter (essentially a Pointman with an assualt rifle), Shield (carries a tactical shield which takes most damage), Breacher (shotgun wielding units for close quarters combat and making dramatic entrances) and Stealth (probably the most dynamic, effective classes, although more difficult to design practical tactics for). Stars earned in finishing levels quickly and with minimal casualties can be spent on new weapons and tools.
The main thing to know is the freedom that this game offers. There are so many ways to fulfil objectives that it is unlikely that in a group of 100 people (maybe even more), one person will use the same tactics and methods of completing the mission. You can choose what units you use, where to put them, where to move them from there, how to enter a building, when to enter a building, and many more.
There are, however, a few cons to this game. For instance, it is very common for the game to quit responding while launching for the first time in a while. After quiting and relaunching all is normally resolved, though it is worth mentioning. Also, unit control occasionally will act up, allowing me to only control one officer at once. A simple quit of the level will normally fix the issue though. I am fully aware of how unimportant these are, and in turn will note these are not significant enough to be a reason to not purchase the game.
All in all, Door Kickers is a marvelous example of how games of the genre should be, and deserves more attention. I would give it 9/10. Well done, Killhouse.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you remember Rainbow Six's famous planning phase? Did you enjoy that part of the game more than the actual mission? If you answered yes to these questions, Door Kickers is a worthwhile investment.

The game's core features right now are quite good. There is a slight learning curve to get your guys moving the way you want. Sometimes you will feel like you are micromangaging movements especially if you want to execute proper room clearing techniques. And occasionally you get angry at the pathing system since there are numerous house plants and chairs which create impassable barriers. But it is still fun.

There are definitely a good number of missions available of varying difficulty. Some you will breeze right through, others will be the bain of your existence until you get that perfect plan with 0 casualties working just right. Also the random mission generator is always good if you are looking for a quick challenge. As well as replaying missions trying to achieve the single-plan and hands-off achievements.

The loadouts are varied and offer a decent sized arsenal. It is mostly reflective of what a police SWAT team would have available. One gameplay feature I like is how your team really practices good trigger discipline (single shots if possible). While the bad guys will often go full auto at the slightest of targets. One thing that is not completely apparent in the loadout section of the game is what effects do the equipment have on your team. You'll notice in cramped interiors, it takes the man with the M4 longer to train his rifle than the man weilding his pistol. But for those long corridor or outdoor shots, your Assaulter with his rifle is far more efficient than your rear guard weiding his shotgun. Sadly none of this is explicitly described in the loadout menu and will take some experimentation to figure out what the ideal loadout is based on your style of play and the mission.

The graphics and sound are good for a game. It is definitely not a high fidelity sound and graphics visual masterpiece, but that really is not necessary. It is the gameplay which makes this game shine. There are various mods which revamp the sound experience if you are unhappy with the tone of the firearms.

Overall, really fun game!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best games ever. I'm not kidding. I have quite a few games; all Battlefields, CS:GO, Rust, DayZ, numerous race games, all Hitmans, but I prefer this game. Why?

Well, I love this game, you can play it anytime, any duration that you like. Spend fifteen minutes on a plan, or just rush in and control all the troopers in real-time. I prefer a combination, planning a bit ahead and then work further in real-time.

Cons:

- I like the police versus criminals idea
- I like the old-fashion top-down view
- I like that you (new feature!) can throw grenades and flashbangs around corners
- I like the ballistic shields and different weapons
- I like the different roles (shotgun, rifle, pistol, etc.)

What should improve:

Nothing in general, it's a good game. Okay, the AI could use some more unpredictability.

Summary: I love this game! :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Door Kickers. What can I say?

Door Kickers to me is a superb, real time, action-filled, strategic and sometimes infuriating Police game. Fancy taking charge of your own SWAT team that can kick down (almost any) door or blow it up? Want to shoot people and be overly happy when you complete a mission that took AGES but you finally mastered it? Of course you do and Door Kickers is it.

To be serious though the interface is very intuitive if sometimes a bit fiddly  and the stop-time FTL style mechanic means you can keep on top of everything even in the middle of a firefight. The only major thing wrong with Door Kickers is that you MUST be prepared to be patient and repeat missions: on more than one occasion I have yelled and got generally angry with both myself and the enemies, so yeah, be patient, it is worth it in the end. Few other minor things but excusable for a Beta!

9/10 Would kick again.

reviewText:
Great tactical game. Takes a bit to get used to the UI but it works well once learned, it's not a standard rip-off of the Starcraft of C&C interface and this is why people might have a bit of a learning curve before you can get into the gameplay. It only took my an hour to get almost everything memorized, not that bad. This game has random maps, pre-made single maps and campaigns. Going through the single maps alone would take a long long time. Campaigns can take a while especially if you have to restart some particularly overly hard missions. Once you play all those most games would be done and become boring, right? Luckily there is a random map generator. You can set size and enemy parameters, and since you don't know exactly what you are going to run in to it ends up being fun for long periods. Even if I have 5 minutes I can run one or two random killhouse maps. Or if I want to spend 3 hours playing a tactical game I can and it still doesn't get dull.

Tactically there are various ways to overcome each scenario. You can lockpick a locked door or break it down, or you can use special tools to lockpick it faster or break it faster but these tools take up an inventory slot and are heavier. Or you could use a breacher with a shotgun, but that shotgun becomes the primary weapon and is only useful at short range. There is a give and take to each option and all are viable pending your playstyle and how you want to approach that whole level. And this is just locked doors. The constant variation in the maps and multiple ways to approach each type of situation keeps it varied. Some maps you cannot flank the armored guy and have to face him head on, if you do not have the right equipment you will likely suffer. Sometimes there are too many rooms to flashbang each one so you have to adapt to opening doors and clearing rooms in a different way sweeping around the corner from a wider angle. The game doesn't feel dull even after a long time playing. Gameplay is top-notch and the devs plan on adding to it with co-op and multiplayer eventually.

This game has longevity, it hasn't gotten dull yet and I have plenty of hours in it already. It can be played in short spurts or long sessions without an issue. It's a tactical game that requires some thinking. Controls are more than functional and become natural to use with a little bit of time in the game to do exactly what you want down to smaller details like how you want to walk around a corner with a sweeping curve instead of walking straight in. There are various classes that all play differently and can change your play style immensely from one map to another depending on team loadout. You can respec your doctrine points aka skills and you can change classes freely any time you want. I have nothing but good things to say about this game so yes I recommend it. It has been on sale a few times but even full price this is a good one to pick up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Door Kickers is an Action/Strategy game which puts you in command of a S.W.A.T. team. you must use planning and tactics to complete the objective (such as rescuing hostages or defusing a bomb) and keep your squad alive.

The game is played from a top-down perspective and nearly all of the missions revolve around storming a building. there is a variety of weapons and gadgets to aid you in completing the objective. ( such as spy camera's to look under doors, or flashbangs to temporarily blind enemies) With the introduction of BETA. you can now customise the appearance of the member of your squad. as well as change their names and callsigns.

The game also includes a sort of skill tree which allows you to grant extra skills to your squad using points earned by completing levels. there is a variety of skills and more will be implemented as the game develops. (My favourite skill is the one that allows stealth members to hold fire until ordered to shoot)

The game also includes different types of S.W.A.T. members. like shotgunners. assualters. stealth ETC. each mission is different and requires careful planning and certain classes will be more efffective than others.

finally the game features steam workshop integration. making it possible to create and download user created maps, weapons, gadgets and more!

In conclusion. this is a game that is definately worth buying. if you like strategy games. You will like this. The game is currently in BETA and will be updated to include more gear and a campaign mode. i definately recommend it.

reviewText:
Door Kickers is a top-down strategy game that puts you in a command of SWAT team.

You have your SWAT team on disposal and you need to kick many doors (hence the name) and kill many bad guys.
You can plan your assault and/or move your SWAT members in real time, also you can pause the time to make precise instructions for troops.

The biggest plus of this game is modding. This game is not out too long but there are many mods: total conversion, skin mods, weapon mods, levels which can be published to workshop from in-game so this adds to great, infinite replayability.


So yeah, I recommend this game

TIP: don't give names to your squad members of your family and friends because they will get brutally murdered by a terrorist that you missed in that one corner where you didn't expect him

reviewText: This gamme is a game that I personally have been following since the very earliest of early access for it. This game is a fantastic 2D swat strategy game. You go into a mission, observe your environment, see what soldiers should be sent in and at what locations they should be sent in at. This game requires though to complete the variety of mission types with maximum efficiency. This game has given me hours of fun and frustation in equal amounts. This game constantly provides me with the thrill of split second decisions that could save a man or cause them all to die. Now that this game is officially out it has all the features that I myself have been waiting for, this includes multiple campaigns, troop customisation, leveling your squads, a random mission generator, and hours of enjoyment as you hone yours and your soldiers abilities. Overall I feel this game is worth every penny.

reviewText:
Door Kickers is a top-down real-time tactical shooter (shooter in leiu of a more appropriate term - the shooting is automatic and your buds are very competent at running and gunning) in which the player controls a team of SWAT (?) (Armed police, S.T.A.R.S., whatevs) operators tasked with completing an objective at a given location.
The objectives typically take the form of a. Kill all the bad guys, b. Arrest a certain specific badguy, or c. Rescue a bunch of helpless hostages.  In most cases objectives of the B & C variety can be over-ruled by killing all the bad guys anyway.
During each mission, your task is to choose and path your operators through the building/mission-zone.  This involves selecting means of entry, equipping your team with the correct weapons and breach equipment and otherwise generally co-ordinating your buds so they can support each other by fire, hold down certain angles, throw flashbangs and grenades and escort hostages.
The over-world gameplay takes the form of a squad roster in which you may allocate each operator to a specific skill class alongside individual stats and some (seemingly inexhaustible) operator avatars.  From here the player can choose to play a single mission, to gain star economy for in-game upgrades, or embark on a longer campaign - a series of missions which, perhaps with the exception of the first, are enormously expansive and super intricate.
Gameplay is nice, ergonomic and smooth and for the vast majority entirely mouse driven.  Though played in real time, the mechanics hinge a lot on the ability to pause and re-plot paths for your dudes.  Cheevos await anyone who can execute an entire mission from a single plot-line before the mission.
I have only two gripes about the game really. First, the throwing of flashbangs or other grenades through closed doors is somewhat sluggish and counter-intuitive.  Often, though you've set him to peek the door after he throw's the grenade, your trooper will sit idly taking bullets to his non-mobile ♥♥♥.
Secondly, and perhaps minorly, I would love to be able to export my ossom mission completion playthroughs but this function while tantalising me constantly, is not available on Mac.  Devs, plz fix.

These tiny gripes aside, Door Kickers is a fantastically gripping game with a well thought out single player campaign.  The weapons and equipment are good in vanilla and, I must say, enhanced tenfold by Gunworld's IoV - Instruments of Violence item pack.
Excellent game.  You'll be engaged for hours.

reviewText:
Rainbow Six planning phase as a refined standalone game.

This is a top-down pausable real-time strategy where you guide a squad of special forces through various missions (hostage rescue, bomb defusal, arrests, evidence grab or plain good old terrorist hunt). Before the start of the mission you are able to set up a plan and then watch it play out - however you can adjust it to your liking at any moment and have a limited direct control of separate fighters. Furthermore every fighter is customizable with the ability to select a loadout suitable for various tasks (akin to SWAT4).

The game comes with several campaigns and a huge amount of single missions, as well as a battle generator. Missions have a degree of replayability due to random enemy positions and numbers each time. If that's not enough there is a built-in mission editor - meaning you can also download many great user missions from Steam Workshop.

Steam Workshop further offers more variety by having mods that add new squad skins, new weapons and gear.

The only downside of note is an interface, which no doubt was affected by the mobile version - there's a lot of scrolling and clicking through to get to the stuff you want, especially after you've installed some mods. The game also gets repetitive after a while - same as its bigger" brethren - classic R6 and SWAT series."

reviewText: If you love SWAT 4 (or know what it is), then you'll love Door Kickers. Both are tactical kill-the-terries games but they only differ in perspective, SWAT 4 being an FPS and Door Kickers being a Top-Down Strategy Planner. Comparing the 2 games sounds far-fetched but in terms of replayability, customization and difficulty/challenge, Door Kickers gives you that edge just as SWAT 4 did. I've put hours into this game and I just keep coming back for more. :D\n\n

reviewText:
Great tactical game. Takes a bit to get used to the UI but it works well once learned, it's not a standard rip-off of the Starcraft of C&C interface and this is why people might have a bit of a learning curve before you can get into the gameplay. It only took my an hour to get almost everything memorized, not that bad. This game has random maps, pre-made single maps and campaigns. Going through the single maps alone would take a long long time. Campaigns can take a while especially if you have to restart some particularly overly hard missions. Once you play all those most games would be done and become boring, right? Luckily there is a random map generator. You can set size and enemy parameters, and since you don't know exactly what you are going to run in to it ends up being fun for long periods. Even if I have 5 minutes I can run one or two random killhouse maps. Or if I want to spend 3 hours playing a tactical game I can and it still doesn't get dull.

Tactically there are various ways to overcome each scenario. You can lockpick a locked door or break it down, or you can use special tools to lockpick it faster or break it faster but these tools take up an inventory slot and are heavier. Or you could use a breacher with a shotgun, but that shotgun becomes the primary weapon and is only useful at short range. There is a give and take to each option and all are viable pending your playstyle and how you want to approach that whole level. And this is just locked doors. The constant variation in the maps and multiple ways to approach each type of situation keeps it varied. Some maps you cannot flank the armored guy and have to face him head on, if you do not have the right equipment you will likely suffer. Sometimes there are too many rooms to flashbang each one so you have to adapt to opening doors and clearing rooms in a different way sweeping around the corner from a wider angle. The game doesn't feel dull even after a long time playing. Gameplay is top-notch and the devs plan on adding to it with co-op and multiplayer eventually.

This game has longevity, it hasn't gotten dull yet and I have plenty of hours in it already. It can be played in short spurts or long sessions without an issue. It's a tactical game that requires some thinking. Controls are more than functional and become natural to use with a little bit of time in the game to do exactly what you want down to smaller details like how you want to walk around a corner with a sweeping curve instead of walking straight in. There are various classes that all play differently and can change your play style immensely from one map to another depending on team loadout. You can respec your doctrine points aka skills and you can change classes freely any time you want. I have nothing but good things to say about this game so yes I recommend it. It has been on sale a few times but even full price this is a good one to pick up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Door Kickers. What can I say?

Door Kickers to me is a superb, real time, action-filled, strategic and sometimes infuriating Police game. Fancy taking charge of your own SWAT team that can kick down (almost any) door or blow it up? Want to shoot people and be overly happy when you complete a mission that took AGES but you finally mastered it? Of course you do and Door Kickers is it.

To be serious though the interface is very intuitive if sometimes a bit fiddly  and the stop-time FTL style mechanic means you can keep on top of everything even in the middle of a firefight. The only major thing wrong with Door Kickers is that you MUST be prepared to be patient and repeat missions: on more than one occasion I have yelled and got generally angry with both myself and the enemies, so yeah, be patient, it is worth it in the end. Few other minor things but excusable for a Beta!

9/10 Would kick again.

reviewText:
Addictive little tactics game with some smooth action.  This game simulates a bust like on the Wire, or Hill Street Blues. Where the cops beat down the door and then run to catch the perps in the act, and stop them destroying the evidence, or killing hostages.

I like how it builds up the anticipation of what lies behind a door, and then the thrill from the controlled burst of violence necessary to subdue whoever is in there. There are single missions and a campaign. The campaigns, so far, are really just loosely tied together single missions.  But, this is fine if you’re looking for action and tactics and not much story.
The game has many mods and comes with a cool looking editor, for those who want to get lots of replay.
I would love to see a sequel set in Rio de Janeiro or somewhere.

reviewText:
The store page description said it clear:
Real Time with Free Pause
No turns, no hexes, no action points or awkward interfaces
Realistic but action packed
Those points made me buy the game, and I was never disappointed. Door Kickers is best SWAT type tactical strategy you will ever play.
The game offers many customization for your squad, many type of weapons and tools to choose from.
There are tons of missions and campaigns, with ability to build your own mission and share it on steamwrokshop.
The main things that made me really enjoy this game is the planning, the more you plan and make sure you use the right tools in right position the more of chance you will pass the mission, the beautiful thing that once you hit the unpause button you will see how your orchestrated plan going, and if it works as you plan and succeed, you will feel the satisfaction in such way that you will never feel it in any other similar game.
The game use simple 2D graphics, but with many details to reload and recoil of each weapon.
I totally recommend this game for any tactical games fans, it is great value of money.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not one to write many reviews nor do I often play tactics based games like this.  The fact that I am writing a positive review for this game refelects how enjoyable I have found it.  I love the level challenges and find that the difficulty is set just right.  My biggest disappointment is that a very well thought out run can be won or lost by the random location of enemies and/or the enemies' marksmanship.  Sometimes you can blitz through a level with impressive results but re-run a level you only needed a minor tweak to, in order to improve your time, can result in you looping thorugh the exact same plan 30 times before it works again.
There are so many areas to work with and a varied set of levels, plus the ability to make your own or import others, that it keeps you playing.  The RPG like development of team members also adds a good dimension to the gameplay, especially if you play through all the levels with a single squad member

Overall I'd give this game 8 out of 10, the effect of randomising the enemies being the main issue.  I don't expect it to be exactly the same every time but it needs to reduce the luck factor.

reviewText:
Strategic and sometimes brutally difficult.

Still, when the game mechanics work, it is a lot of fun.
Also contains a load of content for a game at this price.

reviewText:
An excellent tactical top down simulation of SWAT raids.

Pro's:
- varied tactical options
- Extensive planning options that are remiscent of the Rainbow Six prescenario phase.
- RPG element allowing SWAT members to level + there is an overall specialization tree for your team.
- A wide variety of weapons and equipment: firearms, explosives, gadgets and more.
- a series of nice campaigns
- a variety of portraits, options to rename and give callsigns.
- diverse and fun scenarios
- combat, hostage evacuation, retrieving evidence,... all passes the revue.
- easy moddability and already a nice amount of quality content out there.

Negatives:

- Visuals could've been better.
- More portraits would've been nice.
- Some sort of good/decent co-op mode would've been fun and interesting.
- An option to be the opposing player in specific and difficult scenarios would have been interesting.

Global judgement:
A must have for fans of tactical combat, extensive planning, tactical puzzles and 'SWAT'.

reviewText:
*** I bought this game during the 2014 year-end Steam sale, and played when I got back to my uni before the finals week, most of the time off-line (>80% of my playtime) due to a massive flood disaster. So at the time this is written, I have played almost 100 hours offline, and only 13 hours with Steam online, which is why Steam only clocks me as have played only 13 hours.

Oh and one more thing: I like writing, so my review is going to be REALLY long.

Now with that out of the way, I'm going to get to reviewing Door Kickers (DK).

What is Door Kickers?You know what Rainbow Six (R6) is? If you don't, scroll down to the bottom of my review where I tell you a bit about R6. If you do, well, that's what DK is, except for three differences:
DK is a top-down tactical shooter / R6 is an FPS tactical shooter
DK is very easy and light to just pick up and play, whenever, wherever. Coffee break, lunch hour, taking a sh*t (if there will ever be a tablet version, which is very much possible if the dev bothers), doing your whatever thing with your laptop at Starbucks, etc.
DK has you control a SWAT team with a considerably wide range of Law Enforcement Organization (LEO)-level gear / R6 has you control a bunch of hardened and specialized team of tacticool genius-level operator dudes and chicks bearing a very-wide range of military-grade toys
That's it. The rest, everything you remember from your fondest R6 days - choosing, equipping and leveling up your squads (with different classes), breach gadgets, planning your maneuvers, your button-hooks, wedges/pies, rescuing hostages, defusing bombs, capturing HVTs, retrieving intel/evidence, or straight-up delivering 'Merica to the bad guys - it's all there, AND THEN SOME:

reviewText:
My enjoyment of this game followed an inverted bell curve - at first I was elated. The dip came somewhere between my 20th and 30th mission, where the difficulty started ramping up faster than I could cope with. I was quite frustrated for a while but kept trying to wade forward. And sure enough, once my knowledge of the game mechanics accumulated past a certain critical mass it was only upwards on that bell curve, toward permanent satisfaction. To limit the length of this review, I'd like to touch up only on things that I didn't like as I'm sure the positives are thoroughly described by others.

there are no collisions between units. While this makes the game easier, I kinda expected having to manage this aspect of CQB - avoiding a jam when moving in cramped spaces. And here instead you can stack your whole squad on one space like some sort of Shiva with 20 arms, wielding 8 guns, 2 tasers and a shield. And it's a very valid tactic.
as an aside to the above, there is also no friendly fire though I don't mind.
there are multi-layered levels (ex. a house with an additional floor) but time moves forward only on the floor you are observing. This is an engine deficiency acknowledged by the devs and it's here to stay. Sort of embarassing.
the interface used for drawing paths is pretty clunky. It's hard to use precisely, and even harder if you're trying to map out a complicated plan in a tight space because of all the markers. It took me like 3 hours and some googling to figure out how to strafe. The option to bend" an existing path is either missing or I haven't found it.
there is a fair amount of bugs
date: particularly related to handcuffing.\nin the hardest
recommended: endgame levels you are kinda undergunned and seriously struggling to defeat the body armor of enemies. I appreciate that police arsenals are not the same as military
hoursPlayed: yet it feels wrong.\nthere is a bit too much randomness in the outcome of firefights. Even the best plan will sometimes be defeated by RNG.\nBut yeah
voteText: in the end I agree with the Overwhelmingly Positive rating. This game will satisfy almost any fan of tactical combat. It's extremely addictive and feels rewarding to improve in."

reviewText:
I had the pleasure of looking at DoorKickers way back in Alpha and then again at the full release version. I'm glad it made it all the way through. It reminds me a lot of the tactical planner in pre-Raven Shield Rainbow Six games. You can carefully plan out your teams entry into an area swarming of enemies and maybe even hostages or adapt a plan on the fly. It can be pretty challenging too! The game has a fair amount of pre-made content for the price and also offers a stage builder to extend that further.

KillHouse Games provided me with a review copy to produce a first impressions video. If you'd like to see the game in motion and hear some more thoughts consider checking out the video below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=POGOjK3BmIk
voteText: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Super little game. Fun enough at the moment that even if development stopped for some reason I'd not feel I'd wasted any money and they're adding plenty of other features/content as development goes on anyway.

If you played the old Rainbow 6 then it has similarities to the planning phase of that but can play/pause as you go (and control the officers while they're running your plan for desperate tweaks etc); I'd be tempted to compare the positioning etc to Frozen Synapse too.

The idea is to achieve the goal of the level; at the moment one of, kill everyone, rescue the hostage/s, make the arrest or disarm the bomb.  There are other goals to get better ratings on each level which are to beat a certain time and to keep as many of your chaps up as possible.

Advancement is both by individual cops gaining in ability and rank, and Squad Doctrine" group training options.

Gear is selectable both by a class (which can be changed per mission) and choices within that class- which specific guns
date: armour and gadgets your chap will carry into the mission.  Some of the choices at the moment are fairly irrelevant and down to small preferences
recommended:
others will have a big effect on how you go through the mission.

POST RELEASE additional comments:

There are a selection of single missions; randomly generated single missions; mods from the workshop and campaigns.  The single missions are sort of training for the campaigns really
hoursPlayed: both yourself
voteText: and leveling your troops/unlocking gear.  The campaigns themselves are perma-death but with restarts though there is iron-man mode which doesn't allow restarting. All in all a pretty vast amount of prepared content and then there are all the mods and randomly generated content making for a pretty near infinite game...and you'll almost certainly want to do individual bits multiple times too.\n\nI've gone through the single missions multiple times now and there's still tactical improvements
helpfulPercent: nuances etc to learn.  They've updated adding more content and more is still to come.\n\nIf you like tactical stuff just do yourself a favour and buy this game."

reviewText:
Team Alpha, go! Bravo, engage!

Pros:
- Doorkickers has a very great tactical element to it, allowing you to utilize unit sight lines to spy corners before entering and taking out the baddies before shots are fired. Using multiple units for cover and movement through doorways, flashing, flanking is very fun and very satisfying when it all goes according to the plan in your mind.
- The different classes to combine on missions is very interesting and with mobility meters could spell the difference between a good outcome on a mission or a very fatal end.
- Utilization of Go-Codes" is always exciting when you are able to time your plan sequences in a smooth
date:
fluid execution.
- There is a SKILL tree and Doctrine points to purchase weapons and gear (only once) for all of your units to use
- Lots of maps and creatable content to share with Steam friends and community.

Cons:
- I have to admit
recommended: sometimes the units can be a bit finnicky
hoursPlayed: and it gets a bit frustrating; there are two tangos in a large room on the other side of a locked door you cannot flashbang through - breaching with a hammer
voteText: lockpick
helpfulPercent: or breaching charge takes too much time to set up
votesHelpful: you send a man through and direct his sight line to sweep
votesTotal: but instead of firing on the first guy he sees on side A
votesFunny: sweeps and shoots man in corner B instead and leaves the first man he sees in the shadows. Alongside the factor of friendly fire sight lines
commentsCount: its frustrating when you have 2 of your own units stacked on top of each other
column16: but one will not fire in his designated direction due to a teammate being directly on top of him.\n- I've found that enemy units are able to fire simultaneously and hit my units while they are in a line
column17: while my units cannot fire through each other. Something I think will be patched in the future.\n- Another issue I'm having is pathing selections: there are times where lines will overlap in a hallway and you wnat to change the sight line of ONE of your units
column18: but you can't select his pathing line because the OTHER guys' line is on top of his. I tried to lock one unit's path with SHIFT
column19:
but doesn't seem to work. Something that can be fixed.

Conclusion:
All in all
column20: I REALLY do enjoy the game. For $20? Sure. I honestly feel the game's INCLUDED content could have been more
column21: the campaigns are a bit short
column22: but the replayability with different tactics is refreshing. The focus on community map content is a bit harrowing
column23: as I'm not one to really have time to download and configure all of it to work. I also feel that each class should have their own type of special ability in relation with the skill trees
column24: instead of just access to a certain type of primary weapon. Different stat fluctuations
column25: maybe? I don't know. It's still a great game to kill time and terrorists with."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game, it's awesome! Even being in Early Access. Usually I'm pretty hesitant on buying Early Access titles, but I was pleasantly surprised by this game. I used to play alot of Frozen Synapse - its just my kind of game. The top down perspective allows me to practice the tactics I training I received in the Marines. And you'll hear that alot from some players: that they play the game exactly the way they would react and conduct these situation in reality. It's no surprise to me that they've gotten a contract to create a simulation title specifically for military and law enforcement, the expressed purpose to be for training and small unit tactics.

Guys, if you're into individual tactics and clearing a building room by room, as well as the intensity involved in jusst not knowing what may be around the next corner for your men, this is the game for you. I purchased the stuff of legends package from their site, which allowed me to not only have a portrait of me in the game for the troopers, but also gave me feature voting rights in the forums. Trust me, the final game is gonna be awesome! It's worth every penny you'll be paying for it.

reviewText:
Highly tactical game that is essentially about finding the best way to get your officers to kill all the Druggies, Terrorists, Junkies, etcetera. The action can be fast and brutal, or slow and methodical, with the multiple classes, dozens upon dozens of missions, and all manner of weapons and potential ways to win in the fast-paced gameplay of Door Kickers.

Open-ended tactical action with loads of potential gameplay, PLUS Steam Workshop and an active modding community. This didn't win 'Best Tactics 2014' for nothing (Rock Paper Shotgun), and I say it shows. Rainbow Six if it was top-down and you were a floating policeman god, some may say (There's also mods to make it Rainbow Six). There's much more, but this is just the tip of the iceberg, I say.

If you like what you're reading, I say go take a look at some (more, if you already have) videos before deciding if you want to spend money on this (because it's smart, of course). Highly recommended for fans of tactical shooters and strategy games alike.

Apologies for any major issues or minor errors, I should be asleep. But Door Kickers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome, who doesn't want to break a door down and blow a terrorist head off?
I've played the game for a couple hours so far, it fun and very interesting, however, remember that this is still an alpha, so not even a beta yet, so don't expect everything to be polished or the game to be at its full. The game can be pretty frustrating at times, for example I don't understand the use of stealth weapons, it doesn't change anything, enemies hear you and come to investigate. I hate this, i like playing stealthy by as soon as one shot from a stealth weapon  goes off, enemies come to see what the noise was then ♥♥♥♥ turns into cluster ♥♥♥♥ central. I do hope they actually fix this, if they did then this game would definitely be on my top 5 game list.
There's this a lot missing from the game, for example not all of the upgrades are available, there's no campaign so you just go through different stages and shoot at people. One of the most frustrating missions are hostage rescue missions, at first they are nice and all but after a couple stages, they start executing hostages, so if you break a door or shoot at someone, you have 5 seconds to reach the hostages before they are executed,  which isn't easy in a big house/office... Also, it seems SWAT doesn't care much for hostages, if they see an enemy and there's a hostage in-between them, they just shoot at them and kill the hostage, which is especially annoying since if you kill a hostage, or a hostage dies, it's mission failed. Don't expect it to be a Call of Duty like game where one person takes on an entire building full of terrorists, you will almost always be out-numbered so you have to plan ahead of time, and be ready to adapt when things don't go your way.  I would recommend this game if you like games like XCOM but remember, this is still an alpha and there's a lot missing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe mechanics in this game are just top notch, they are easy to grasp, can be combined easily, offer a very deep tactical experience, but above all else, they are fun. Any game where you can fail over and over again and still be having fun is a damn good game in my book.

reviewText:
WITHIN 2 HOURS: DOORKICKERS

ALL THE YES
It is a top-town tactical shooter where the goal is to complete CS like objectives against the clock and freindly bodycount
The gameplay when you manage to control the rather hectic command interface is really cool and rewarding as you are able to plan where your own custom SWAT team goes to looks and use items to interact with the maps, Say A guy flashbangs a large room and everyone piles in, You waste a bunch of terrorists but don't check your corners as well as you could have and a hidden good picks a guy off with an innacurate burst of SMG fire but he gets picked off and you complete the mission
It is all about how well you are able to use your team and their equipment at hand to deal with the threat on the map and it is glorous
And the progression and replay value at a glance looks great too as there is a very wide variety of weapons avalible for each of all the 4 unique classes in the game, individual cops (alongside your own progress bar) are able to gain XP on the field leveling up and getting better as the game goes on

Overall: ALL MY YES

Door Kickers is an excellent blend of strategy, tactics, puzzle soving, and a nice blend of RPG elements such as character leveling. reviewText: Door Kickers is a tight, well-designed tactical strategy game. It's fairly easy to pick up and has a decent amount of depth. It actually has a surprisingly exciting tone, much more intense than most strategy games. You can spend qute a while perfecting your plan, but missions go down in a matter of seconds, which makes the game feel fast-paced. You can try to complete the operation without pausing for that extra challenge.\nAll in all, it's a really fun game. My only criticism is that it is a little bit *too* tight (insert your dirty-minded laughter here). Basically what I mean is just that the game can get tiring after a while because all the missions start to feel predictable, especially once you've analyzed the underlying systems.\nDefinitely recommended, but you probably shouldn't expect to get more than 10-20 hours out of it.

reviewText:
Awesome game, simple graphics, 2D, and yet very fun. It's a tactical strategy game where you customize your own squad, names, callsigns, loadouts, and roles (like shield, stealth, assaulter, breacher and pointman) and assign them to missions, and there are a ton of missions, premade missions, campaigns, community-made missions, mission generator and mission editor as well. The replayability is enormous and you can just keep playing different missions for hours.

Different objectives like hostages, bomb defusals, pure hostile killing, etc, The design of the plan system is very nice and well-made, you can plan out tactics and pause at any time of the game. You can make a whole plan from the start of the mission, or you can play a more real-time playstyle where your plan is improvised as the operation goes, or a combination of both.

If you are interested in conducting anti-terrorist/crime operations(e.g. SWAT) and is not too picky with the graphics, you should definitely give this a try.  It's got the Rainbow Six/SWAT atmosphere but the gameplay style of XCOM converted to real-time.

9/10

reviewText:
Don't bother reading any more reviews because I am here to say BUY THIS GAME. If you have any interest in tactical teams and tactics in general then this is for you. Anybody can jump on a first person shooter and go for a run but this is the first game that even comes close to the immersion that the SWAT franchise gave us in terms of entry team decision making.
Do you want to go in quietly and plan every single corner down to the tiniest detail? Or do you want to throw thirty flash-bangs and fill the room with lead?

This game is totally epic and I was not expecting it to be this fun.

Pros
+plan your route right down to individual arcs and tasks
+cause mayhem or sneak in with silenced weapons
+HUGE replayability

Cons
-would love a bit more gear and weapon customization

Gameplay 9/10
Tactical options 8/10
Soundtrack 10/10

reviewText:
If the trailer interests you in the game, then get it. It's as good as it looks.

If you liked Frozen Synapse but wish it was a little more organic and less chess-like, this is your game.

If you like re-playability through perfection, then 90% of the scenarios have medals that you can earn by beating it under one of three conditions. (You can do them all at the same time or in separate runs).
1) Lone Wolf - Complete the stage with one team member deployed.
2) Real Time - Do not manually pause the game from start to the end of the operation.
3) One Plan - Create a tactical plan for your team, then succeed using that plan without any interference from you.

Also a 3 star rating for each level. Did you beat it within mission par time? Did you lose any men?

Tons of scenarios to keep you busy (100+), and even a couple campaign modes of increasing difficulty. (Not really any story, but there's links between each level)

Lots of backdrops. Cruise ships, Grocery Stores, Bars, Police Stations, Autoshops, docks, subways, vacation homes... you name it.

Possible Scenarios: Bomb, Hostage, Elimination, Execution (Hostage but with a timer), and Robbery.

This game is amazing. Oh yeah and there's a mission editor and Steam Workshop support. WHAT. Get this game.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I got this game in early September 2013, when it was in early access. I liked it as it was then (and it was well worth the rather cheap price at that point), and it has only improved. I see that it won best tactics game of 2014, and this makes me feel a little pride, knowing that I have supported it from the beginning :)

Your team is pretty customizable. You can rename each trooper, select from a number of different portraits, choose each trooper's class, and also customize their equipment and weapon loadout. There are several different campaigns to undertake, each with different focuses, enemies, and situations. There's also a bunch of individual missions you can try.

For extras, there is a mission generator, map editor, and you have access to the workshop. You can download maps, etc from the workshop which is always nice.

The gameplay is characterized by pausing and unpausing (or, not). You can pause, and while paused click and drag each trooper's path through the level, designating actions to do once they reach a door (like flashbanging it and clearing), which way to scan when they reach a certain point, and so forth. You can map out as much or as little at a time as you want. There is a bonus if you successfully run through the level fully mapping it out in the beginning, and not interfering. There's also a bonus for completing the level with just 1 trooper. Hopefully this makes sense.

The selection of equipment and tools, combined with classes, can make for plenty of replay value. You could run 1 level many different ways depending on which troopers you use, what equipment they have, and how they enter a building, room, or area. For instance you might run the level very differently if you have one or two stealth troopers on the mission, than if you have a pointman with a pistol, assaulter with a rifle, or breacher with a shotgun.

I certainly recommend this game.

I got Door Kickers as part of a Humble Bundle so I was pleasantly surprised when I got an awesome game that I didn't really intend to buy!

This game is awesome. Great mix of paused and real-time gameplay. Can't really say anything good about this other than what you've already seen in other reviews.

reviewText: Door Kickers is a tight, well-designed tactical strategy game. It's fairly easy to pick up and has a decent amount of depth. It actually has a surprisingly exciting tone, much more intense than most strategy games. You can spend qute a while perfecting your plan, but missions go down in a matter of seconds, which makes the game feel fast-paced. You can try to complete the operation without pausing for that extra challenge.\nAll in all, it's a really fun game. My only criticism is that it is a little bit *too* tight (insert your dirty-minded laughter here). Basically what I mean is just that the game can get tiring after a while because all the missions start to feel predictable, especially once you've analyzed the underlying systems.\nDefinitely recommended, but you probably shouldn't expect to get more than 10-20 hours out of it.

reviewText: A lot of people compare Door Kickers to Breach & Clear, and even The Masterplan. Where this is probably a good comparison in terms of genre and what to expect, Door Kickers is far more fluid and boasts a rather active community giving the game experience a slight edge over Breach & Clear and perhaps a lasting experience.\n\nThe concept is pretty simple. You run a SWAT-like squad which you are able to level up through single missions (training") and get to equip them with weapon and armour upgrades as you complete missions
date: level up your squad and gain "roster stars". These you spend on upgrades. You can also gain a type of skill point that you can use to improve the 3 basic weapon trees: hand-guns
hoursPlayed: shot-guns. These all become bigger
voteText: brighter and better as you progress and start to unlock other roles for your squad: breacher
helpfulPercent: assaulter
votesHelpful: stealth and a shielder.\n\nThe workshop community have already created a large array of mission rooms and campaigns
votesTotal: but there is also an editor in-game and random room creator that help to gain those level ups before tackling the storyline campaigns.\n\nThis isn't your Real World SWAT team. Don't expect negotiation abilities
votesFunny: or actual SWAT tactics to retrieve hostages. The game borrows from SWAT. Once you can accept that
commentsCount: then the game is pretty fun. You can stop/pause to plot within the mission or campaign
column16: or run it fluidly which I think really adds to the atmosphere of the game. Fog of War obscures rooms and areas
column17: so trying to clear out a biker gang hideout
column18: or safely escort a VIP from a train station can be daunting
column19:
exciting and full of action if you don't pick the right squad members or plot your actions carefully.

Leave no door unopened. Even if it is a toilet. Tangos hide in toilets.

Overall
column20: if you want something harking back to the old SWAT games
column21: you may not like Door Kickers not keeping to SWAT regulations and realism. Otherwise
column22: if you like using spy cameras to check out rooms for the bad guys
column23: breaching with a shot gun
column24: or using a shield guy as a decoy whilst you flank from behind some cars in a parking garage
column25: you will probably really enjoy Door Kickers."

reviewText:
If you've played S.W.A.T or the Early Rainbow Six Games, you'll love this.
It's gives an amazing topdown perspective, making it possible to live out your autistic C.O fantasies of sending many a man through fatal funnels.
The controls are easy to grasp, but allow for extremely complex plans as you unlock items and squad classes.

Decent modding community is also a plus.

8/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Doorkickers feels a little bit like Rainbow Six 3, without the FPS part.

You manage a squad of 2+ (depending on the mission) officers who have to clear a building, secure evidence or rescue hostages.

Before starting the actual mission, you are to forge a plan of how to tackle the situation.
You can give orders to each officer individually so that in the end they work together to clear the building as quickly and safely as possible.

You may also give each officer different weapons, or a completely different class.
Need a shielder? No problem.
Or rather a breacher? You got it.
A stealther? Sure.

If you are not satisfied with certain aspects of the game, the modding community is doing their job for sure.
From different/new weapons or armours, to completely new classes and obviously loads of user made maps.

The cartoonish graphics are definitely no throw off. You will be way too focused on your tactics trying to keep your officers alive than to check out the beautiful flower pots in the bathroom.

Just don't go thinking Easy peasy". You will have your squad killed easier than one would think. A proper planning phase is half a victory.

Now grab your gear and get on the truck. We are Oscar Mike in 5. Barricaded suspects holding a hostage which you need to rescue!"
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fantastic game, has a few bugs with task switching and crashing a handfull of times over twenty hours. Incredible amount of content.

A lot of the nuance is hard to come by even with a lot of playtime, some steam guides proved invalubale. A lot less fiddly/granular than Frozen Synapse but this makes it more fun somehow. Would love to see an XCOM mod/version with more destructible objects.

Can be very random, a plus for some, as makes some scenarios much harder to solve. Some campaign missions seem like junk but it might just be me thats junk at the game. (VIP escort through street and a massive cruise liner mission).

reviewText:
The best top down special forces/armed warfare strategy games I have played.
Now, the good...
1. Units can react to different events on their own (no micro-micro strategy)
2. You organize the overall plan, very tactical with even the capability to have different points, so you can say move to point A -they will move to the pre planned locations, then move to point B etc...
3. Mods increase the scope of the game drastically
4. Stellar music,fits the game well
5. Small additions such as realistic tactical radio speak adds to the athmosphere

Now, the bad...really had to think up of ones but they are both not too important though!
1. campaign could be better? more interactive perhaps with cutscenes?
2. multiplayer mode, you command one squad the other guy command the other

reviewText:
GREAT game that was well worth the price (woo holiday sale!)

Planning out your unit's movements and facings is surprisingly intuitive, and the go-code mechanic helps keep your guys coordinated. Your units feel competently trained but not godlike, and the enemies are challenging without being frustrating. Pretty much every time one of my units dies, it's immediately apparent it's because I forgot to plan for some variable/check that corner/messed up my pathing/some other personal error rather than my units not shooting straight.

Each officer can be customized with different class, weapons, support options, armor, and a tool, and each choice feels meaningful. For example, if I want the officer to stay in the back of an open area and provide cover, I'll make him an assault and give him a carbine for range and stopping power and heavy armor since he won't have to move as much. If I want to run the same officer through a drug bust, I'll change him to a pointman (stealth once I've unlocked it), give him a silenced pistol and light armor so he can quickly and quietly run through the hideout and secure the evidence before it's destroyed.

The game almost feels puzzle like, in that it encourages players to find the optimum route through each map to guarantee success no matter enemy placement (something the game tests by mixing up where the enemies are on each map) with a well though out plan, rather than simply winging it on the fly (although that is possible, especially if you want to make effective use of the spy cam). Notably, the player is rewarded on some maps for executing the perfect plan by planning everything once, then hitting go and doing nothing but watch the action. It maintains a good balance in difficulty as well. The game rarely feels too easy, but it also rarely feels frustrating or overwhelming in difficulty.

Progression is surprisngly well thought out, starting players on a simple kill house with a handful of badguys and a pair of officers, cutting their teeth in before introducing door entry, different classes, hostage rescue, and arresting/escorting mechanics.

I haven't messed with the ingame editor yet, but its very presence almost guarantees near infinite replayability. Currently, there is a wide selection of challenging single missions, and four campaigns (a string of 5 or 6 missions), with a 5th having a confirmed release date and more being promised.

reviewText:
very easy to learn as the controls are quite simple, but quite an in depth game thats highly addictive.
one thing i really love about this game is that it takes about 3 seconds to load to the main menu, after which everything instantly loads the second you click it. that means i can load up and be straight into it within a very quick amount of time.


drawing a path for your team to follow is quite fluid, if your wobbly on the mouse your teams path will be too.
insert commands easily onto that path, so they will CLEAR !  a room before moving on, strafe a certain direction, or wait for a go code.

use the single missions to level up your team, unlock better weapons, shields, armor, tools etc by earning stars. once something is unlocked its free to assign to any other team member.
once your team is good enough you can start doing campaigns.
theres virtually hundreds of maps to choose from, and a steam workshop to add even more gear and maps.

unlock new squad types like assaulter, breacher, shield and improve them by earning doctrine points to spend on perks for each class.
weapon type and loadout will have a big effect on how your team maneuvers, its fire rate, accuracy, stopping power or clip size.

assaulting an airplane to save some hostages? maybe the pistols will allow you to maneuver around easier and change targets quicker to fire off a few well placed rounds rather than trying to use a clumsy shotgun or spray machine gun fire about.

use a camera under the door to spot targets, blow open the door, flashbang, give the go signal with a go code" to assault rooms full of terrorists from different doorways

reviewText:
In my years of gaming, I have seen many great products come and go. Great products like Rainbow Six and SWAT as they made their mark in the gaming world. You tend to look back on those games and ask yourself this question. Does anyone still remember those days? How they helped pave the way for tactical strategy in games?

When Door Kickers came along, the answer couldn't have been more clear. ♥♥♥♥ yeah we remember!"

What's good about the game:
-The deep tactical planning
date: choose from a wide variety of weapons and equipment to plan your approach. (You can even change their names if you're into that sort of thing.) Use your troopers to their maxium potiental to get the job done and bring everyone home safe. Espically in Iron Man mode you will have to take your planning very seriously as every  trooper death only makes your job harder.\n\n-Open-ended planning
recommended: missions can be completed in several different ways. It will be up to you to determine what is the best course of action.\n\n-Random enemy placement. In most if not all cases
hoursPlayed: the odds will be stacked against you. You will face off against several tangos (bad guys) armed to the teeth and not knowing for sure of how many  are there or their location adds tenson to the action. Just because you have a plan figured out
voteText: doesn't mean things can't go wrong.\n\n-The ability to do two different playstyles. The first being a pause
helpfulPercent: plan
votesHelpful: action playstyle. Before your troopers get into the thick of it
votesTotal: you can pause the game and develop a course of action for them. Tell who to go where
votesFunny: where to look
commentsCount: where to strafe
column16: etc. Then watch it unfold when you switch it to real time. The second being what I call wing-it mode. You can play the entire mission in real time and make things up as you go. So players that aren't into the whole stop and think style aren't forced to play that way.\n\n-Numerous amount of missions and counting. There are several missions to be completed in this game
column17: all of which have a lot of replayablity to them. Single missions
column18: campagns
column19: custom player-made missions
column20: randomly generated missions. It feels practically endless to what can be done to have missions.  Furthermore
column21: as of the time of this review
column22: the developers are still adding missions
column23: content
column24: and improvements to the game.\n\n-Mod support. Something about the game you want to change up? Things like new weapons
column26: etc? Odds are there is a mod that fits the bill and there are quite a few to choose from.\n\n-The bits of comedic relief. Though this game has an overall serious tone
column27: there are bits of humor thrown in that is quite amusing to lighten the mood a little when needed. It's not obnoxious or intrusive ethier
column28: it's well timed and unexpected.  I'm not to going to spoil them as I'll leave them to be discovered yourself. ;)\n\nI honestly can't think of anything serious to complain about with Door Kickers. It's an overall well made and addicting tactical strategy game that is worthy of your money and time.  Even at full price

you get a lot for twenty dollars.

reviewText:
This is an enjoyable yet highly frustrating game mired by conflicting design decisions and implementation as well as a suspect UI and control scheme that has clearly not been created for PC.

7.0/10 as of 29/4/2015 (14 hours of gameplay)

On the positive side, it's a lot of fun at the basic level and replaying single levels over and over again is very rewarding using different tactics and weapons. Attempting to complete levels using a single trooper or one complete plan is even more engaging and rewarding.

The game fails when you start unlocking further upgrades/weapons/setups and attempt some of the more complicated levels. This is where you need some intricate planning and split-second decisions and reactions count. And this is where the poor UI fails and where the design flaws start to actually matter.

Some of the really annoying issues include:

-inability to sync moves beyond the A B C D go-codes. Frozen Synapse does a WAY better job at that.

-you can't change a trooper's angle of view and swap weapons/reload in the same move. One action will cancel the other so either you have to unpause, execute the 1st action, pause, and queue up the 2nd one, or you have to create a redundant move point in order to queue up your 2nd action. You should be able to queue up 2 such basic actions simultaneously.

-you can't edit or move any waypoints in the middle of a chain. Everything after the point of edit is deleted and on those long complicated levels this is SUCH a waste of time!

-in some levels, the game forces your troopers into very small quarters and trying to select them and order them around becomes a nightmare. There's no SELECT ALL feature so trying to get your troopers onto the 2nd floor is very annoying. Also the way the game selects which troopers are moved between floors seems pure random. I've failed so many missions because I kept switching between floors trying to get everyone in one place and end up being flanked and killed during the time I've wasted.

-I've no idea how this game expects you to play it in real-time mode with such bugs and weird control scheme. Some keyboard hotkeys would be nice.

I'm still recommending it because I've got my fair share of fun for the price I've paid; I got the game on sale for 50%. Until this game becomes more PC friendly, I wouldn't recommend getting it at full price. The ability to mod and create/share your own content is awesome but I really need tight gameplay and proper user-feedback to enjoy this game the way the developers intended me to.

reviewText:
Wanted to log at least 10 hours into the game before I wrote anything about it.
Now I have, so here it goes.

This game. Is ♥♥♥♥ing. great.

I'm the type of person who enjoys tactical games. From strategy games (Company of Heroes) to tactical shooters (Arma series, CS:GO, anything involving tactics) to turn based tactic games (Arma Tactics, other misc mobile-esque games of the such) This game fits the bill perfectly for a tactical experience. It's fast paced enough to keep tensions high, and the ability to pause and issue orders lets you think before you act. Unfortuantely, I was raised in the Post-SWAT games era, so I've not had a chance to play SWAT 4 (anyone want to sell me their copy? Kidding of course); but this game comes about as close to the experience as I think I'm going to get. I'm well on my way to 20 hours, and the way I approach video games is, if I can get a 1$/1Hour of entertainment ratio, it was money well spent, and that is certainly going to happen with this game.

reviewText:
This is a game about door kicking. You get to kick a lot of doors, under many different circumstances. You have a squad of door kickers who somehow get better at other things, but not so much at door kicking.

Usually there are people on the other side of the doors you kicked. They don't like you and shoot at you. I can only presume they are upset because they would have liked to kick the doors themselves. You can buy better weapons and armor to deal with these unpleasant interruptions better so you can get back to door kicking.

Some doors can't be kicked right away. You have to do things to them first. Basically, they're playing hard to get. But they want to get kicked, and you'll kick them eventually. You know they like it.
