reviewText:
Doorkickers is a fun, challenging shooting puzzle game with a tactical paintjob and some forgetable RPG elements.

Let me start by saying that Door Kickers is not what I really hoped it to be: a spiritual successor to the Swat line of games. Remember those? They were the counter to most shooting games because you could get the best victory with the fewest shots fired. A careful and well-planned approach was more useful than  running and gunning. Being cautious was almost always better than being fast.

Door kickers has none of that. The goal is generally to kill everyone besides your team that has a gun on the map.

DK isn't a police simulator or even that much of a tactical simulator (for reasons I'll go into below)- it's a puzzle game. But it's fun and I found it delivered plenty. In general DK wants you to complete the mission without losing any of your guys and in the shortest time possible. This usually means killing all suspects but you're also tasked with preventing the execution of hostages and demolition of bombs. Keep in mind not only are the suspects absurdly numerous but they throw grenades at your guys. Yeah.

There are also some extra goals for each mission, like using a single trooper, not pausing, or using only one plan. These are sometimes neat little challenges but other times are frustrating or, sometimes, impossible due to the design of the mission (some impossible challenges have been removed in patches, I suspect more will be later). As I said there's not much cautiousness allowed if you want the full score for a mission. Instead you go in fast and if it doesn't work, just restart and try again. Repeat until you succeed below the time limit. It seems the newly added campaign missions are a little less strict for time.

You can build your squad but there's not much individualism there. You can put backer's names and faces in to personalize a trooper but that's it: no backstories, special skilles, interactions, etc. Fans of Jagged Allience (or to some degree Swat 2) shouldn't expect much here. Troopers advance in 3 skills as they go along but I honestly can't tell much of a difference between an expert and novice trooper.

You can gain your whole squad certain skills\upgrades which are sometimes useful but many are bizarre in that they replicate what should be normal behavior. For example: being able to hold fire when not under threat. Given the micromanagement elsewhere I don't see why it's even an upgrade instead of an inate ability. It's really tiring to be trying to do a stealthy approach and the guy you've armed with a carbine decides to blow away an enemy across the map who has no idea what's going on, thereby alerting everyone. The skill" in question would also be much more useful if it were a toggle rather than the way it is implemented as a button that must be pressed every time one wants to fire. I'm also not sure how a squad needs to "learn" how to open doors instead of noisily kicking them. I've tried both
date: and opening a door is easier and more tactically sound!\n\nThere are lots of guns and devices. Most are redundent and add little but it's nice to have some variety. Some of the weapon stats are very unrealistic. It seems that a .45 caliber pistol is easily more powerful ('stopping power') than a UMP45
recommended: which is basically the very same cartridge in a longer barrel and therefore more velocity. Looking at the stats it might even be more powerful than a assault rifle! It doesn't make any sense and I'm not sure if it's as a 'balance' issue or rule of cool.\n\nThere really is no arresting necessary
hoursPlayed: except for those missions that present unarmed subjects specifically targeted for arrest. Nor is it easy to arrest suspects
voteText: as they never voluntarily drop their weapons and the troopers don't give them a chance to do so anyway. The only real way I've found to arrest armed suspects is to tase them and then cuff them while they are disabled. This is a tricky and very risky move when there's more than one suspect around and there's really no reason to do it since putting a bullet through someone leads to the same result.\n\nThe enemy AI is pretty dumb. There's a mod to leave dead bodies on the ground instead of having them vanish and I think I know why it is not the default... it looks absurd how many bodies will be lying in the same spot. You'd think once you kill the first 3 guys who walk out a door there would be a change in tactics. That would be a mistake. By all means
helpfulPercent: keep shooting them as they march out as if they're cattle. The only thing stopping you is the need to occasionally change magazines (from your unlimited supply) and the time ticking away. But on later missions the poor AI is hidden with absolutely STUPID levels of armor for the enemies who
votesHelpful: while still dumb
votesTotal: will manage to murder your troopers immediately upon seeing them from 150 yards away. ♥♥♥♥
votesFunny: why don't we hire these criminals? They're vastly better than anything the good guys can do. Plus they never have to reload (had a guy firing a shotgun at me for 2 minutes without pause).\n\nFriendly AI is also robotic (the only thing giving the bad guys a fighting chance in addition to their absurd numbers and lots of access points). You need to micromanage everything if you want to get a good result
commentsCount: to the extent where you need to manually direct the troopers in a 'slicing pie' movement to clear a doorway (otherwise they'll tend to sorta just charge in and promptly get shot). Troopers will respond to being shot... eventually... but that seems to be the only stimulus that will get their attention. They seem to be of two minds as to whether they'll address a threat in an area not specifically designated as 'their' cover zone. Usually this means they'll ignore it if it's important and engage it like flies on ♥♥♥♥ if it's NOT important. So if there's two bad guys and one is disco dancing while the other is moving to shoot the hostage
column16: it seems like the troopers go for the dancer. Well
column17: okay
column18: can't blame them for that
column19: but I wish there was a way to designate a target out of several visible.\n\nSo if it sounds like I'm negative about this game
column20: it's just because I wanted something a little more like Swat 2. But the game is addictive and if you buy it knowing you're getting a tacticalish puzzle shooter you can have a lot of fun. It's nice to play things out in slow motion and the RT\Pause action works quite well (on single story buildings). Watching the replay afterwards can be fun as it brings everything together. The dev-team seems responsive to the community and there is modding (as well as a mission editor). It strikes me as one of those games that just demands 'one more try' even when you should probably be out mowing the lawn. I believe I paid $15 for the early access and that seems to me to be a good price-point for the game."

reviewText:
I like what this game going for.  However, I have several problems with this game.

Editing paths when making a plan  is a hassle.  I wish it was something I can overlook but since it's the main tool to use in the game,  I can't.  It's not efficient so you have to workaround the problems with UI. I really hope they clean this up with door kickers 2, if not then I'll be pretty disappointed with that game.  I don't think this game would have such positive reviews if everyone had to finish the missions without pausing since the there are several issues with UI.

I like how the AI reacts to your actions such as busting down a door.  I'm not too fond of them being able to spawn in random/different locations.  The reason for this is because it can be tedious coming up with a solid plan as editing paths are a pain. If they imrpove the UI in door kickers 2 then I wouldn't mind random spawns for enemies.  You may find several problems with your plan if it involves flashbangs.

Switching between pause and real time sort of eliminates some of the problems that come up when making a plan.   It's cool in a way, I'm glad it's there, but then it's not really challenging.

$15 would be a more appropriate price tag in my opinion.

BUGS:
An obnoxious buzzing sound that won't go away happens often when loading a new level.  Usually, it goes away when you restart so it's not a big issue.  But I saw iron man mode? that you can enable and I believe it mentioned something about not being allowed to restart missions.  I don't know if it causes a problem there.

reviewText:
For those who have struggle systems and wish they could cop Rainbow Six: Siege, Door Kickers is more than just an adequate substitute; it is a tactical game worthy of play and praise on its own terms. KillHouse Games has done its homework in terms of researching the qualities of guns such as the P90, the Benelli M4 (Joint Service Combat Shotgun), Tarvor, SAR-21 and more. This research extends to considering factors such as cornering with large weapons and reload speeds. For those looking for a good tactics game, they need not look farther than Door Kickers.

Full Review at Geeks Under Grace	[www.geeksundergrace.com]

reviewText:
Let me start this off by saying I only gave a thumbs up judging strictly as a game, at it's current price I would give a thumbs down.

I wish the had a middle option when recommending. It is good enough to not get a thumbs down, but it is not quiet what I expected. It's pretty fun and I will put more time into it when i'm bored, but so far in just an hour and half i'm ready to get back on frozen synapse instead. I find the controls very awkward in comparison to frozen synapse and breach & clear. It's definitely a more casual game compared to those others. The squad customization is very nice and there is a lot of maps / scenarios to choose from. This is a game that I would say is worth it all depending on the price. If I were to have paid 20$ then I would be extremely dissapointed, ended up only spending 4$ b/c I bought cards for super cheap to convert to gems. I don't think this game is really worth more than 10-12$ in comparison to other games in the genre, but those other games are more hardcore type and this has a more arcade / laid back feel.

One of the most frustrating things is that when you set multiple waypoints there is no key to delete the last WP and you can't hightlite it then hit delete key. The only way to delete every single WP is to click on then then right click and select delete. Maybe not a big issue for some of you, but go play frozen synapse and then try to not have that feature. There are no straight lines in this game when making your WP, you simply drag the mouse the entire length then go back and adjust how you want to aim a long the path. This of course ends up with somewhat wavy lines across the path which again is not a big thing unless you are use to better games which use straight lines that auto adjust more WPs when you hit a wall. To me it's a little annoying to have to hit A, B, C or D in order to pause a unit at said spot, but i'm also use to frozen synapse giving you a timer so you can have a unit go, turn, kneel, wait 2 seconds, stand up, turn around, go forward, wait .4 seconds, turn right, turn left, run forward, run past avoiding enemy and then target them from around cover all in one simple command.

This does have an option a lot of people will like which is being able to play it without really pausing it at all just drag the units quickly adjust them and switch units very fast. I personally don't like that, I prefer more tactical pausing with extreme level of detail, but it is a good feature allowing you to play multiple ways. I'm sure as I casually spend some bored time with this game that I will eventually get these controls down very well and enjoy it a bit more, but for right now it just feels clunky and awkward. It gets a bit tricky to see whos path is whos when you have more than 2 people.

This game could be great for you, it all just depends on what exactly your looking for. If you are really into the very detailed, highly precise tactical turn based games then you might be dissapointed. I would spend 5$ more and buy frozen synapse if you have neither of the 2 games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDoor Kickers is a really good game which I recommend to all of my friends, but also to all the internert strangers. At first it is daunting to get all the basics down, but once you have those and know how to work your team, it is an absolute beaut of a game. It always feels great when I manage to clear out a level full of hostiles quickly and quietly, managing to save all the hostages from execution. It is a simple game to use, but it is also challenging at the same time, as it is no easy achievement to gain all three stars on all the levels. If you don't get it until now - BUY THIS GAME! :)

reviewText:
A lot of fun in Door Kickers comes from the failures.

And unless you're endowed with the tactical genius of an Alexander the Great or Napoleon Bonaparte, you're going to fail a lot.

Door Kickers is a top-down tactics game with an emphasis on positioning, planning, and reaction. The game tests your ability to adapt to unfavorable circumstances, and it often pits you against seemingly insurmountable odds in the form of armed thugs.

All in all it's great fun. Feels very rewarding when you craft a plan for a particular mission and you pull it off successfully. Would urge you to wait for a sale though, as the base $20 price dropped down to just $4 in this past Autumn Sale.

reviewText:
Simply the best swat tactical game u can ever have played!
This game has a iron man mode and for those who dont know what that is it basically means if a person dies in ur team he stays dead forever.
U can customize ur swat members which adds a bit more depth to ur squad as u try to keep urself or even ur friends alive XD ur swat members after every campaign and ur swat members WILL DIE sometimes due to bad luck, bad planning etc..BUT ur swat members who died will be replenish with fresh recruits after every campaign.
Gameplay....Simply amazing...U will start of as a rookie squad of swat members and u will gradually build them up to higher lvls and u will definitelty want them to come back alive trust me XD and increase ur squads level to unlock 4 classes currently.Which all play out very differently.The assaulter who wields the mg, The shield guy who is basically a meat shield for ur men and the pointmen who are very mobile so that they can get to the hostages fast before they are killed.....
After every mission u get rosters which are basically points for u to buy new weapons, armour, gadgets ..etc for ur swat team.
Now mods also extend this game's life as modders mod this game with new campaigns and levels which increases the replaypility which is awesome!
A must have for hardcore players who love strategy :)

reviewText:
NOTE: This review was last updated on 19 Dec, 2014 @ 4:49pm. Things I talked about may now be irrelevant. I will update this review in the near future as I have stopped progressively playing Doorkickers.

As much as want to enjoy Door Kickers, as I am a big fan of Tactic RTS's , this one has given me the most frustation yet, and not in a good, challenging way either. Although my hours spent on this game at the time of this review is few, the movement mechanics have already hindered a positive impression from me. Often times, the fault in my plans is not in my ability, but in the broken mechanics of the game.

When things work out and bugs such as shooting at the wall because the target is to my characters adjacent isn't a problem, the game is fun. Watching my team swiftly move in and clearing the area under a designated time feel rewarding and I can see what the dev's envision. But, having a constant struggle with things like redoing my carefully laid out plan because adding a step would somehow erase the previous ones, or, being unable to peak around the corner of a doorway because the action menu of breaching methods block my cursor from selecting my move node, breaks the experience for me.

Among all my concerns however, the two big annoyances are when my team disregards the assigned command call (ex. Alpha, Bravo), and moves in on their own, and, when the units move before clearing a newly breached room. The work around for for the first issue is to redo my whole plan which, as mentioned before, is a chore that takes away from the fun.

Although my review has mostly been negative, this is not a bad game at all. In fact, I would recommend you to give it as try as this review is soley based on my own critique. You may overlook these minor flaws and thoroughly enjoy this game. But for me, these minor issues were little details that became a major hassle as I played on.

reviewText:
I cannot recomment this game in good conscience.  It is a great concept, but its excecution is so flawed that it is often more frustrating than enjoyable!

There are a number of bugs/flaws which makes for a frustrating experience.  For one, you cannot delete all the checkpionts, so you find yourself making mistakes and then having to undo your entire plan because a point that you definitely do not want, decides it wants to stay.

On top of this, the men do not always listen to your commands.  I have a mission where I have to breach a number of doors and my men surprise me by deciding if and when to throw their flash bangs!  So I went to 80-90% success, only to have this kind of ridiculous mistake happen and have to start all over!

Your men are in fact untrained dumbskies!  If, for example, they are told to breach a door, but that door gets opened by the enemy, your men get to that point and sit there like sitting ducks.  So you can have a perfect plan that goes down in flames because a door, which they think they need to breach is already open and they don't know what to do from there.

The randomness is a bit too random, sometimes, baddies are just piled into a room, so a perfect plan goes bad because you simply cannot cover everyone.  In real life, thee men do not hang out in three corners of a room waiting for something to happen!

There are a lot of missions and content, but they all seem to be the same.  It would have been much better if the missions were progressive, you learning new skills and dealing with intentional situations.  This feels like empty game play that is very redundant.

These combined makes the game too frustrating to truly enjoy!

reviewText:
I cannot recomment this game in good conscience.  It is a great concept, but its excecution is so flawed that it is often more frustrating than enjoyable!

There are a number of bugs/flaws which makes for a frustrating experience.  For one, you cannot delete all the checkpionts, so you find yourself making mistakes and then having to undo your entire plan because a point that you definitely do not want, decides it wants to stay.

On top of this, the men do not always listen to your commands.  I have a mission where I have to breach a number of doors and my men surprise me by deciding if and when to throw their flash bangs!  So I went to 80-90% success, only to have this kind of ridiculous mistake happen and have to start all over!

Your men are in fact untrained dumbskies!  If, for example, they are told to breach a door, but that door gets opened by the enemy, your men get to that point and sit there like sitting ducks.  So you can have a perfect plan that goes down in flames because a door, which they think they need to breach is already open and they don't know what to do from there.

The randomness is a bit too random, sometimes, baddies are just piled into a room, so a perfect plan goes bad because you simply cannot cover everyone.  In real life, thee men do not hang out in three corners of a room waiting for something to happen!

There are a lot of missions and content, but they all seem to be the same.  It would have been much better if the missions were progressive, you learning new skills and dealing with intentional situations.  This feels like empty game play that is very redundant.

These combined makes the game too frustrating to truly enjoy!

reviewText:
For those of you who enjoyed the planning phase in the original Rainbow 6 games. This is a full game made out of that with a few extra features.

For those of you who didn't, its a realtime tactial strategy game, played from a top down perspective where you deal with different situations by commanding your team to breach and clear rooms. kill tangos, and attempt to complete a variety of diffenet objectives and challenges.

As you level up you unlock more abilities that improve your team as well as new weapons and equipment. Its very good and I highly recommend it. You can even install a mod that tha changes the sounds effects and music to that of the orginal Rainbow 6 Rogue spear. Sold!

reviewText:
Despite being a pretty simple game, Door Kickers is extremely well implemented. The gameplay is smooth, challenging and quite exciting once you get going.

The system it uses for upgrades is initially a bit frustrating, requiring a bit of grinding to get enough stars to buy decent equipment but once you get past the first hour of gameplay you'll have most of the end-game items you'd want.

For once, the single-mission content is larger than the structured story-line missions to the point where I still haven't managed to finish them all yet. The challenges are a bit on the simplistic side though, I'd like to see a wider variety of bonus challenges (like finishing a map using a specific type of trooper, or without firing a shot) but it's hard to complain with something like 100 levels to master.

Definitely worth a purchase, and certainly not unfinished content.

reviewText: Decent game, but definitely not very tactically deep, and certainly not very fun gameplay-wise. The gameplay itself boils down to mastering a room clearing technique, and once you figure this out, the game becomes very simple. Not much variety in the inventory, and frankly, once you unlock the Assault class, you have everything you need to beat the game outright. The RPG elements that are introduced are very shallow and don't really differentiate your squad members. The various roles in the squad are pretty superfluous, and at later stages, Assault is the only really valuable role you can take. Cover system is very mediocre, with your troops more or less being a gun that you point with your mouse. No dynamic AI, no functional cover shooting. What you have is a game that consists of everything that made the old Rainbow Six games good, but without the same polish that made them fun. Fun diversion for a few hours, but not an 8/10 game.

reviewText:
Amazing game, well worthy of all the praise it gets.
The developers are constantly updating, tweaking and adding to the game, and I hear that there is even a multiplayer/co-op mode coming, either for free in a patch, or maybe as paid DLC. Either way, I will take it. These guys deserve every penny.
One of the only truly great games to go through early access AND it actually made it to a full release AND it is still supported by the devs now.
Very easy to just start playing, it's one of those games that is pretty easy to learn, but difficult to master, especially as the maps go on and get bigger and the enemy get smarter and much much tougher.
Workshop support is nice, and there are some truly stunning mods out there, such as the highly rated sound mod that adds almost 100% realistic weapon sounds to every gun in the game, or the many many weapon packs out there that add great weapons from P-90 SMG's to the aliens pulse rifle (ridiculously overpowered, but still good fun).
The progression system works nicely, the skill tree is good (although a little small), adding some nice abilities" to your troopers
date: such as knowing how to use cover better
recommended: better aim with pistols or whatever
hoursPlayed: using double-tap to make sure enemy are put down quickly. All work nicely to bring your officers in line with the rising difficulty as you get to the tougher maps later on.\nI seriously can't recommend this game enough. Whether you want to plan as you go

reviewText:
It's a really good tactics game.

Pros
- Tons of levels.
- Tons of armour.
- Tons of weapons.
- Tons of utilities and support gear.
- Voiced characters.
- Alternate appearances for characters.
- Workshop support.
- Level creator.
- XP which leads to upgrades.
- Allows mission replays so you can see where you went wrong if you died.

Cons
- Female officers will speak like men.
- Can be very difficult during some missions.
- Caps aren't available when customizing callsigns OR names.
- Steep price tag if it isn't on offer.
- REALLY, REALLY fiddly to give your officers directions. 4/5 times you try to flash bang a door, then go through, the UI will just reset and make you redo your plan again.
- Some missions are damn near impossible to complete. Fire gun. Oops they heard, hostage is dead. :^) Fire taser. Oops they heard, hostage is dead. :^) Try and stealth it, shoot the bloke who's closest to the ONLY hostage. Oops you failed it.

reviewText:
Although I was really looking forward to playing this title, I was very disappointed about the gameplay. The tactical side is unplayable in my opinion. XCOM and Breach & Clear are far better titles in that respect. The turn-based tactival gameplay in those games is just superior. In this game it feels clunky, un-fair and completely random. You cannot choose which way your soldiers look, you cannot get them to look around corners and stay in cover that way, the planning is awfull and that just turned me off.

I do like the soldier-interface and the levelling aspect of your team's capabilities and weapons, but that just doesn't make up for the clunkiness of the rest of the game.

I might just be spoiled by the above mentioned games, which might make this review a bit biased, but as there are alot of positive reviews for this title, I am not very concerned about the impact this review will make.

reviewText: This game has some interesting ideas, but the execution of them is laughable. The controls are unbearable, as it is impossible to map out a good plan of clearing rooms without deleting your route ten times over. The randomized enemies make this game a boring game of trial-and-error. The same plan can just as easily kill all your team members, or it might just grant you 3 starts. Completely arbitrary...

reviewText: A solid, fun little game, that suffers from a lack of polish and explanation. Gameplay mechanics are good, and the controls are very simple. They can be picked up very quickly without any kind of tutorial. This is fortunate, since the game does little to explain itself other than a few hints on the controls in the opening missions, and a How To" that says the same information. Unfortunately
date: any further explanations of game mechanics

I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves REALISTIC STRATEGY games.
- Provides 5 different unlockable classes of S.W.A.T soldiers

- Single missions (different scenarios)
- Realistic campaign (if a soldier dies, he stays dead for the rest of the story)

and
- Workshop items and mods available

reviewText: One of the best Tactical games I have ever played hands down.  Similar to Frozen Synapse that came out a few years ago but in all ways superior to it.  The ease of giving units direction and the ability to pause or command your units in real time make this game so fun.  It's also challenging, there are times to beat for each mission and you have to pass levels with one gameplan you create to have your units move in fluidly and dispatch all targets.  It is really fun to set up part of the plan, hit play, see how it pans out and then edit it accordingly and add on the next steps.\n\nI can'trecommend this game enough to people who like tactical games.

reviewText:
An awesome game. A 2D Rainbow Six is a nice way of describing it, but it's less FPS and a bit more tactical.

It can be somewhat challenging to get used to the controls, since its gameplay is very unique.

There's also lots of content available, not to mention the mission generator or editor. Out of the box, the game provides more content than you would expect. Totally worth buying.

One last thing, the Linux version works great and is very smooth.

reviewText: Perfect bite-sized strategy with all the 'one shot gravitas' and faux bravado a good round of Rogue Spear would muster. Part puzzle part strategy with some pseudo RPG elements. Tons of stock levels, a random mission generator, and a strong mission editor mean lots of replay value even if you never touch the effortlessly integrated Steam Workshop for mods or community levels.\n\nIt was an impulse buy based on looks and concept, and surprised me in a good way. If it looks even remotely appealing to you, get it!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I played this game and enjoyed it.

If you liked the old SWAT tactical shooter, here's something you will enjoy.

The good thing about this is that there's actual planning invovled - ypou don't just send your men in guns blazing, cause that way most or all of them will go back in bodybags. Here you have to plan ahead and every room you clear matters. One unexpected event will often demand of you to re-think your strategy. This is NOT a game wher eyou plan, then hit execute" and forget about the whole thing. Far from what it may seem from screenshots or short videos
date: this is a thinking man's game.\n\nAnother good part of it is that there's more replayability than meets the eye. The same scenario will vary from one playthrough to the next. You may encounter different number of foes
hoursPlayed: with different behaviour
voteText: armament and patrol patterns than you seen in your last playthrough of a given scenario. There are a lot of scenarios on tp of it all.\n\nThere is also an RPG-style mechanic - your SWAT agents will rise in skill after participating in missions
helpfulPercent: you will also get access to more armor types
votesHelpful: weapon and doctrines as you complete more missions. Doctrines act much as passive bonuses in mmorpgs. This works pretty well
votesTotal: although it is primarily a tactical game and the rpg elements are not as deep as in complex mmos.\n\nOnly two downsides I can think of are two elements from the SWAT games taht I miss here - there's no tear gas and there's little in the way of opponent morale - 99% of foes will fight to the death and not surrender."

reviewText:
This is hands down the most strategic, tactical, fun game I've ever played. Granted I grew up playing SWAT 2 so I have a slight bias but the fluidity and freedom make for the most badass 30 second clips that I used to dream of as a kid. Thank you devs for not only making an awesome modern isometric SWAT game, but for making it RIGHT.

*Tons of quick missions, create your own, or just randomize (BEST feature)
*Plenty of weapons to use and earn the right way- by playing.
*3 campaigns that seem to offer some really cool situations.
*Very precise movement and great UI to represent Field of vision and aim direction.
I could go on... but I don't have to, if you like SWAT or tactical greatness in general you should just pick up this ♥♥♥♥ing game.

reviewText: Door Kickers is the best top down tactical simulator in the world in my opinion, and I have played a lot of top down simulators. Door Kickers has very rich components, from its music to its tactics. The music is extremely atmospheric, making it feel like Payday 2, except you're the tactical advisor. The tactics are extremely rich, giving you so much space to establish the best path and tactic to get the mission done. And you have a lot of customization for the SWAT Officers on your team, whether he/she would be a pointman or breacher, wielding a shotgun or rifle.\n\nThe client is also very smooth and slick, allowing for uninterrupted and smooth gameplay. And with randomly generated doors to kickdown, the game is endless and can be educational. Making sure your officers never forget to check their corners and always stop before entering a room when your fellow officer hasn't caught up with you. This is a very realistic tactical simulator and is an essential game to stratagy lovers.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very promising early access game. You control a swat team from a top down perspective, and command them. It plays like an rts but with a pause mechanic, so you can pause the game whenever you want, and take a look at your situation and issue commands. The game really feels complete already, it feels polished and is full of content. If you run out of vanilla content, it has steam workshop as well. Definitely worth the small asking price of $15. If you like forming a complex plan, and then watching it all play out, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll make this quick: First of all, as you can see in my final rating, this game is great and shows high potential!
I'm saying this because, as of now, the different weapons, equipment or gear in general doesn't seem to make such a big difference on the outcome of a mission. Quite frankly, I didn't even notice that you can customize your squad (except for whom to deploy in a mission) until about the middle of the game! I'd wish to see more impact on the missions based on my setup, etc.

Other than that: Bravo ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Graphics is good, no bugs that I can see. The only gripe I have is that there is no tutorials beyond the basic 3 slides in the game. I know the devt mentioned that there is no point doing a tutorial at this stage, but it does make the game rather steep to learn.

But there is nothing more satisfying than to see your planned mission go off smoothly once you figured out the basics.
I do wish that the characters would not moving into the room before the flashbang go off though...
And the stopping the hostage execution scenarios are hair-pulling exercises.

Better than Frozen Synapse in that the graphics are more engaging, and keeps me interested during the mission, and the pause-anytime-to-plan feature is fantastic.
Looking forward to more improvements by the devts!

reviewText:
Good old Rainbow Six is back. Only this time without the FPS part.

The game is very simple to get into and controls are easy. Music and sounds get you pumped up as you spend your time planning your mission.

Positives: Action packed tactic and puzzle missions, unlocks to be had, team progression, kit selections, moddable on top of all the content and missions which the game already has.

Negatives: Needs more background sounds, I'm tired of hearing Bush speak. Missions and campaigns have a too big difference in awards. Would be nice with hotkeys for ALL commands (switching to secondary, planting breach, flashbang).

Thanks to Lirik from Twitch for showing this game.

reviewText: The most fun I've had in a while. RAINBOW SIX MOD. Door Kickers is a top-down strategy games where you control little guys in smart ways. They have guns, save the things, the things die, or the thing does not explode. This is how you win. You can create maps FULL of things and have lots of fun. This game is really cool and for 14 dollars there really isnt much to complain about. There is a basic talent tree that somes up to which weapon you want which little guy to use and how you utilize it. You can customize your team in a boatload of ways. I like this game. You might too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Based on the 21 June 14 Beta:

I watched a Nerdcubed Alpha Detective on Youtube for this and it looked fun. Only had a small discount in the Summer Sale, but got it anyway. So glad I did.

Massively addictive game and has that one more go" feel. Just playing through the single missions trying to 3 star them all. Has that X-com trait of being protective of your leveled up guys.

Only criticism so far is that the guns seem too similar. There are 7 or 8 hand guns and the best one is easy to unlock so its pointless to even bother with the ones in between. The better Assault rifles have a better leveling up/unlocking range.

Don't normally bother with game editors
date: but going to try on this - seems easy to use from the little play I had.\n\n"

reviewText: Door kickers currently has five different campaigns of various lengths and difficulties. It also has 80!!! stand alone missions to practice with your squads. The game has a lot of awesome content. The interface is user friendly and doesn't take long to learn. While the game is paused you can give orders to your officers and design a route for them to follow.  You can play the game in real time too if you like to live dangerous. The squad members are kept on a roster and they sort of grow on you. I love this game.

reviewText: Very nice and rich tactical squad game ! You will take control of a SWAT team and have save hostages, difuse bombs or kill ennemies in close quarter environment. The gameplay is very rich and efficient. You will have a lot of fun at playing it. This is more than a die and rety simply,This game will ask you to recognize tactics and planning of the assault. You can assign different teamroles to the unit like assault, breacher, shield... and choose your gear (rifles, guns, equipments) The longevity is big with plenty of different missions with ennemies locations changing each time. This is a very good bought I've done and for the prce you can not regret it. In this style I do not know better game !\n\nCe jeu est une super pioche. Le contrôle d'une escouade SWAT dans les environnements urbains vous demandera, voire exigera, de la planification et du bon sens dans l'assaut. Les scénarii et missions sont très nombreux et le gameplay très intéressant bien que simple. Vraiment je ne regrette pas cet achat. Super dans le genre tactique/stratégie !

reviewText:
Highly recommended for all fans of tactical games. It's already a very addictive and fun game and it's just alpha!

It's quite similar to Frozen Synapse in some ways, but it's pausable real time(you will pause quite a bit) instead of being turn based. This kind of a plan & pause system is perfect for the game. You have a wide selection of weapons to choose from and there will be squad progression with promotions, etc. It's great now and it will be even better when all the features are implemented.

----------------------------

Post release UPDATE: The game is now better than ever. Many things are improved and implemented, including individual trooper level progression, campaign and iron man mode(missions can't be restarted, but you get double EXP), etc.

The game is even better with the Rainbow Six character and sound mods (available on Steam Workshop!)

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game. I really love it. Even in Alpha the game was great, nearly without bugs and now in Beta it is better and better. Thanks to workshop it is much more fun, new maps, weapons and changes are available and developers are still working and they are doing great job.
You control group of soldiers (depends on a map how many of them are in action) and you are forced to find the right tactics to solve different situations. Save hostages, Kill all hostiles, Stop execution (this is probably the most hardest mode) and bomb defusal - including few of the combined.
Game is sometimes a big challenge and sometimes very easy - but still fun (although sometimes frustrating if you can not kill the hostile before he kills a hostage)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs a huge fan of the SWAT games I've had my eye on this for some time. After checking out some of the early access reviews I decided to dip my toes in and see what this game had to offer so far - so far, I'm not disappointed. At this stage, the different classes of character don't seem to come into play but I look forward to sending a stealth team in and perhaps even non-lethal options at a later stage.

reviewText: Love the concept of this game. It reminds me a lot of the first Rainbow 6 game back in the late 90's but from a top down view. I played the heck out of that game back in the day. There is some great nostalgic feelings for me when I boot this one up. It's great to see the continued project like development as part of early access. If you liked the old Rainbow 6 or Ghost Recon games but always wanted to see your dudes from above in a strategic environment, this is the one for you.
